thread.title: California to big-league ballplayers: Stop chewing tobacco
thread.title_full: California to big-league ballplayers: Stop chewing tobacco

title: California to big-league ballplayers: Stop chewing tobacco
text:
California lawmakers do what Major League Baseball couldn't accomplish, ban tobacco chewing By JOHN ROGERS Associated Press   3:24   3:24   
Photos: 
FILE - In this Sept. 23, 2015, file photo, San Francisco Giants starting pitcher Jake Peavy works against a San Diego Padres batter during the first inning of a baseball game in San Diego. California lawmakers have taken the first step toward banning smokeless tobacco in state ballparks. (AP Photo/Gregory Bull, File) 
FILE - In this Feb 7, 2015, file photo, Tulare Union High School's Ashley Alcantar wears a mascot T-shirt and makes a "U" sign after scoring the correct answer in a quiz in Porterville, Calif. Four California schools will be forced to change mascots after Gov. Jerry Brown signed legislation barring public schools from using the Redskins name for sports teams. (Chieko Hara/The Porterville Recorder via AP, File) MANDATORY CREDIT 
LOS ANGELES â€” California lawmakers have taken the first step toward accomplishing something Major League Baseball could never do: Stop players from stuffing those big wads of chewing tobacco into their mouths during games. 
With Gov. Jerry Brown signing a bill earlier this week banning the use of smokeless tobacco in all California ballparks, the practice now seems headed toward the sport's endangered species list. 
California has five of Major League teams and owners themselves have been pressing for a ban for years. Last May they got one in San Francisco. In August they got another in Boston. And when Brown signed Assembly Bill 768 on Sunday one was already in the works for Los Angeles. 
Major League Baseball still needs buy-in from the players, however, because the statewide ban that takes effect before next season has no provision for enforcement.
